results.title: Panorama: cancer
results.brief_description: Discusses the nature of cancer, the facts which research has revealed and stresses the need to intensify clinical research. Prevention is important and must be publicised particularly the need to reduce smoking. Suggests forming a central international clearing house for data on cancer to speed its control.

results.title: Panic in the streets [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Sol Siegel, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Elia Kazan
results.brief_description: This noir suspense was filmed entirely on location in New Orleans, and shot in an improvised semi-documentary style using many local non-actors. Richard Widmark plays a city medical officer, racing against time to stop a plague epidemic of huge proportions. The initial carrier was an illegal alien, who has been murdered by criminals who have themselves contracted the disease. Widmark defies official resistance and immerses himself in the seedy underworld of the New Orleans wharf district, in order to hunt down the killers who are characterised literally as an unhealthy ‘menace to society’. Cast also includes Jack Palance, Paul Douglas, Barbara Bel Geddes and Zero Mostel. Music by Alfred Newman. The film won an Academy Award for best motion picture story.

results.title: Panels of the altarpiece: Stefano di Giovanni known as "Sassetta", Siena around 1392-1450. The Polyptych of San Francesco at Sansepolcro (1437-1444)
results.creator_credit: Alain Jaubert, Delta Image, Musée du Louvre, FR3 and La Sept
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Palettes”.
Commissioned in 1437, as a tribute to a Franciscan monk, the altarpiece for the church of San Francesco was to take seven years to complete. Sassetta was paid the highest sum for its time for a painted work. In the sixteenth century the painting was dismantled and dispersed, so that today twenty six fragments are dispersed throughout ten museums around the world, and some have disappeared. The film looks at the genre of the medieval altarpiece, and paintings of St. Francis as well as the innovative techniques that Sassetta used.

results.title: Panel beating and paint work
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Panel & paint”.
Provides instructions for the serious amateur panel beater. Introduces the essential tools, rust treatment, paint preparation and minor body repairs. Professional advice and demonstrations are given, leading step by step to the perfect job.

results.title: Pandora's box = Die Buchse der Pandora = Lulu
results.brief_description: A chronicle of the last months of Lulu’s life has been extracted from Wedekind’s play with more emphasis on thematic and psychological continuity than dramatic unity. Pabst portrays a gallery of characters ranging from the masochistic Schon to the compulsively psychotic Jack the Ripper - and Countess Geschwitz, the screen’s first unequivocal lesbian - with psychological acuity. Lulu, guileless and sexually ambiguous, is to Tony Rayns “the literal calm eye of the storm”. Further, Brooks’s performance is “passive” yet vital, suspended with candour and precision between innocence and childishly fleeting - but intense - emotions. Her emotional vitality and Pabst’s unobtrusive cutting on action make Pandora the most “modern” of silent classics. Cast includes Louise Brooks, Fritz Kortner, Franz Lederer, Carl Goetz, Carl Raschig and Alice Roberts. Adapted from Wedekind’s plays “Erdgeist” and “Die Buchse der Pandora”. Review by Tony Rayns, Monthly Film Bulletin, May 1974.

results.title: Pandora's box
results.brief_description: A delightful experiment in social satire. A large box floats into view, then begins to revolve and change shape. Doors open and close to reveal quick snatches in color of zooming airplanes, TV commercials, silent movies, a mouth spouting gobbledygook, and, finally a loop of film which is eaten by the box in one gulp. Is the box our world?

results.title: Pandora
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, ONF | NFB and Derek May
results.brief_description: Experimental filmmaker Derek May and colour cameraman Martin Duckworth collaberated here in a surrealistic retelling of the old myth. A film of technical experiment with forceful, colourful effect and creative use of shadows.
